repnme.cdata!: Developing preventive health care in Albania

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            developing preventive health care in Albania. Each year,
            four hundred new cases of breast cancer were diagnosed in
            Albanian women. Most of them were discovered at a late
            stage, when the disease had advanced, was hard to treat, and
            often resulted in death. Health System Modernization Project
            supported by the World Bank, put four mammography machines
            in four big cities in different areas of Albania. The
            testing was free to all patients. A new campaign was
            launched urging health care practitioners to routinely
            screen women for breast cancer and to refer them for
            mammograms so that early diagnosis would both increase
            women's chances of living longer and reduce medical costs

25653915.trustfund:
TF033404-ALBANIA - HEALTH SERVICES REHABILITATION,TF033348-ALBANIA - HEALTH SERVICES REHABILITATION,TF027981-TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CTF FOR ALBANIA,TF031160-HUNGARY - HEALTH SECTOR,TF021392-HUMAN RESOURCES DEVELOPMENT,TF053326-PHRD-ALBANIA: HEALTH SYSTEM
            MODERNIZATION PROJECT,TF055804-PHRD-ALBANIA: HEALTH SYSTEM
            MODERNIZATION PROJECT-860458

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory
            while project sustainability is considered
            "limited." Both World Bank and Borrower
            performances are rated as satisfactory. The main lessons
            flowing from this project are: The Staff Appraisal Report
            indicated that the upgrading of hospital and primary care
            facilities would be accompanied by closures or downsizing of
            the services provided in those facilities not selected for
            upgrading. The project design provided no resources or
            activities to support this streamlinin gprocess, and assumed
            that staff redeployment and resource allocation would be
            automatically implemented by the local health authorities.
            The design underestimated the level of effort and resources
            to achieve a heath service rationalization, and may have
            overlooked the technical and poltical complexity associated
            with such activities. In the future consider preparing a
            regional health plan in advance of any future health service
            rationalizationplan to ensure better integration and
            coordination amon the different elements and stakeholders in
            the planning process. In addition the project would have
            benefited from strengthened maintenance management capacity,
            a review and discussion of the main findings from technical
            assistance activities, and allocating specific resources for
            monitoring and evaluation. The District Health Management
            training program offers an effective model for designing a
            flexible recruitment of trainers. The report also evaluates
            procurement and supervision.

18156112.admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia
18156112.trustfund: TF031160-HUNGARY - HEALTH SECTOR,TF021392-HUMAN RESOURCES DEVELOPMENT,TF033348-ALBANIA - HEALTH SERVICES REHABILITATION,TF027981-TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CTF FOR ALBANIA

abstracts.cdata!:
The Health Services Rehabilitation
            Project will help prevent deterioration in health status
            during the economic transition by improving the quality of
            basic preventive and curative health services. This will be
            accomplished by upgrading primary and secondary facilities
            to minimum sanitary and physical standards, improving
            treatment skills of hospital physicians and nurses and
            building capacity at the central and district levels to
            manage health resources and implement sectoral reforms. The
            project consists of a main component to rehabilitate primary
            and secondary health services, and a complementary component
            to build institutional capacity at the district and central
            levels. The first main component will support: 1)
            rehabilitation and upgrading of 100 primary health centers
            out of an initial network of 200 in six pilot districts; 2)
            rehabilitation and upgrading of two secondary referral
            hospitals; 3) strengthened capacity to plan and implement a
            comprehensive public health facilities maintenance program
            (buildings and equipment) through development of maintenance
            norms and staff training. The second component will provide
            assistance to: 1) improve management of basic health
            services at the district level; 2) provide in-service
            training for hospital physicians and nurses; and 3) build
            institutional capacity at the central level to improve
            sector planning, health financing and drug distribution.
